node.title: Judge orders Amazon to reinstate fired activist worker
node.description: Gerald Bryson led a protest calling for Amazon to do more to protect employees against COVID-19 early in the pandemic.

node.title: Brother of youngest Boston Marathon bombings victim finishes his first
node.description: Emotions ran high after Henry Richard, 20, finished the race. His brother, Martin, was eight when his life was taken in the 2013 bombings.

node.title: Covid-19 update: Five further deaths and 8270 new community cases today
node.description: Another five people with Covid-19 have died and 8270 new community cases have been detected, the Ministry of Health says.

node.title: PM's trade delegation to Asia: Three weak Covid-19 positives
node.description: The cases are understood to be from previous infections, meaning they will not be required to isolate, but they will not be able to continue to Japan.

node.title: South Africa army to send 10,000 troops to flood zone
node.description: The South African military says it is deploying more than 10,000 troops to help with relief and rescue operations following the devastating floods that swept through parts of KwaZulu-Natal province…

node.title: Reserve Bank 'not in a good place', admits governor
node.description: Supply chain shocks and the Russian invasion of Ukraine have exacerbated inflation pressures, RBNZ's Adrian Orr has told an International Monetary Fund seminar.

node.title: Sri Lankan president says he regrets crisis, expands cabinet ahead of IMF talks
node.description: Sri Lanka's embattled president has announced 17 new ministerial appointments, notably leaving out members of his own family, and expressed regret for his government's handling of a devastating…

node.title: 'I expect that it will be rising': Robertson on new inflation figure
node.description: The Finance Minister expects the official inflation figure to rise when it is released later this week. Audio

node.title: Mother with breast cancer says Omicron surgery delays frightening, lonely
node.description: A woman who had her breast cancer operation delayed twice in the Omicron outbreak feared the "dangerous strangers" in her body would get the better of her. Audio

node.title: Waiheke Island hospitality businesses co-ordinating through group chat
node.description: A group of 27 restaurants and bars on Waiheke Island have turned to WhatsApp to co-ordinate their opening hours, share staff, and combat pandemic pressures.

node.title: Returning to the office: 'Significant turning point' in hybrid working models
node.description: Skills Consulting Group wellbeing says many workers are now so comfortable at home, they are getting permission to stay.

node.title: Pulse too strong for Magic
node.description: The Pulse have continued their dominance over the Magic with an emphatic 52-39 win in their ANZ Premiership netball game in Rotorua.

node.title: Athletes code switch in Commonwealth Games celebration
node.description: Athletes working towards the Birmingham Commonwealth Games have gathered for a day of competition to celebrate the 100-days to go milestone.

node.title: 'It's frankly a little bit insulting' - Some teachers underpaid for months
node.description: Hundreds, and possibly thousands of new teachers have been under-paid since the start of the year. Audio

node.title: Waikato farmer gets home detention for environmental crimes
node.description: It was the fifth prosecution laid against the farmer by the Waikato Regional Council.

node.title: Russia's offensive on eastern Ukraine has begun, Zelenskyy says
node.description: In recent weeks, the Kremlin declared the capture of the Donbas its main goal of the war after its attempt to storm Kyiv failed.

node.title: Search resumes for Tōrere fisherman missing since Easter Sunday
node.description: The search for a fisherman who has been missing since Sunday in the Ōpōtiki District settlement of Tōrere continues today.

node.title: Three children injured in car crash on Auckland's North Shore
node.description: Police say the children have moderate injuries and have been taken to hospital.

node.title: King wins in Manchester
node.description: New Zealand squash player Joelle King has won the Manchester Open, beating top seed Sarah-Jane Perry of England 3-0 in the final.

node.title: Kimberly Guilfoyle meets again with Jan. 6 select committee
node.description: Her appearance comes nearly two months after Guilfoyle and her lawyers abruptly ended a voluntary interview.

node.title: Employee dies after fall from height at Ports of Auckland, company says
node.description: The employer of a person who died this morning at the Ports of Auckland says the person fell to their death.

node.title: Ardern lands in Singapore on trade mission as travel hiatus ends
node.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has touched down in Singapore after a clean Covid-19 test cleared the way for her first overseas trip since 2020.

node.title: Multiple airlines allowing passengers to go maskless after judge's ruling
node.description: Delta, United and American are among the airlines no longer requiring face masks.

node.title: Coast Guard suspends search for man who went overboard from cruise ship
node.description: It's not yet clear why the man, identified by the Coast Guard as Tang Tran, went overboard.

node.title: Latest U.S. weapons assistance arrives in Ukraine
node.description: The U.S. military will be training Ukrainians outside Ukraine on using U.S.-provided Howitzers in coming days.

node.title: 'New day for democracy': Councillors react to representation changes
node.description: The imminent cutting of rural ward councillors in Gisborne has prompted a range of reactions from elected members.

node.title: Person in critical condition after workplace incident in West Auckland
node.description: A person has been critically injured at a workplace in Massey in West Auckland this morning.

node.title: Raisi says Iran will target heart of Israel if it acts against Iranian nation
node.description: Iran's armed forces will target Israel's heart if it makes "the slightest move" against the Islamic Republic, President Ebrahim Raisi says, amid stalled talks to revive a 2015 nuclear pact.

node.title: Easter road toll down but safety advocates urge ongoing caution
node.description: Four people have died on New Zealand's roads over the Easter holiday period, down on last year's toll of nine. Audio

node.title: 'This brings up a lot of heartache': Fifth fatal shooting by police in Taranaki since 2000
node.description: The fatal shooting of a man by police in New Plymouth over the weekend has brought back bad memories for those in the Taranaki region, says a New Plymouth city councillor. Audio
